Sentence: Record profits for its investment banking advisory businesses and vast improvement in its trading results contributed to the gain.
JPMorgan Chase Posts 68% Rise in Earnings

As JPMorgan Chase prepares an investment book to circulate to potential bidders of Chrysler, American and foreign auto companies, private equity groups and investment banks are chomping at the bit to inspect the struggling company’s financial data.
“Everybody will take a look,” a senior executive at a global car company, which will be eyeballing the book, told The New York Times.
Many Are Eager to See Data on Chrysler
JPMorgan Chase will resume onshore equity broking services in Pakistan after an absence of five years to gain a share of a stock market that has grown 10-fold since 2001.

The move underscores a rebound in emerging markets, which have recovered since the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks in the United States “There is more liquidity and the market capitalization has gone up,” Reza Rahim, a senior country officer, told Bloomberg News.
“The Pakistan market has cheaper multiples compared with other emerging markets.”
JPMorgan Brings Equity Broking Back to Pakistan
JPMorgan Chase & Company and Citigroup said they were changing some cardholder rates and fees that lawmakers say unfairly hurt consumers.
2 Big Issuers to Ease Some Card Penalties
A bid by a private equity consortium to take over Qantas Airways appears to be in trouble after improvements in the airline’s earning prospects have left the offer looking inadequate.

The Airline Partners Australia consortium, which includes the Texas Pacific Group, Macquarie Bank and Allco Equity Partners, made the takeover bid last year, valuing Qantas at 11.1 billion Australian dollars ($8.75 billion).
At the time, many were surprised that the bidders believed the airline was worth so much, but with recently growing passenger loads and stable fuel prices, that view has changed.
“The underlying conditions in the airline market have improved and have made the original bid look a bit skinny,” said Matthew Crowe, the transportation analyst at JPMorgan in Sydney.
Bid for Qantas Losing Favor
CCMP Capital Asia and a unit of the Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan agreed to buy the Yellow Pages unit of the Telecom Corporation of New Zealand for 2.24 billion New Zealand dollars ($1.6 billion).
CCMP Asia, a buyout firm spun off from JPMorgan Chase, and Teachers’ Private Capital will pay 2.17 billion New Zealand dollars in cash for the print and online directories, Telecom New Zealand said.
Telecom New Zealand also expects to get 75 million New Zealand dollars from the unit’s debtors, and plans to use income from the sale to return capital to shareholders, it said.
New Zealand: Investors Buy Yellow Pages

EARNINGS REPORTS The following companies are scheduled to release earnings reports this week: Citigroup, Eli Lilly, Mattel and Wachovia (Monday); TD Ameritrade Holding, Comerica, CSX, Dow Jones, EMC, Intel, I.B.M., Johnson & Johnson, Mellon Financial, Northern Trust, Wells Fargo and Yahoo (Tuesday); Abbott Laboratories, Commerce Bancorp, E*Trade Financial, eBay, JPMorgan Chase, Motorola, PNC Financial Services, Allstate, Bank of New York, Tribune and United Technologies (Wednesday); Advanced Micro Devices, Altria Group, Continental Airlines, D. R. Horton, First Data, Gannett, Google, Merck, Merrill Lynch, Nokia, Schering-Plough, Southwest Airlines, UnitedHealth Group and Wyeth (Thursday); Caterpillar, Honeywell, McDonald’s, SAP, Schlumberger and Xerox (Friday).
Looking Ahead

Morgan Stanley is poised to sign an agreement with Citigroup, Goldman Sachs Group and JPMorgan Chase on rules for trading loan derivatives in Europe that may triple the $8 billion market within a year.
Banks Close to Signing Off on European Derivatives Pact
JPMorgan Chase executive Timothy Ryan has withdrawn from consideration to become the U.S. Treasury Department’s top international official, the White House said on Thursday.
“He withdrew himself from this opportunity for personal reasons,” White House spokesman Tony Fratto told Reuters.
J.P. Morgan Official Withdraws from Treasury Nomination

JPMorgan Chase is threatening to move thousands of employees from Midtown to Stamford, Conn., if New York officials do not give it a larger subsidy package to build a 50-story skyscraper near ground zero, The New York Times reported.
Chase Says It Will Move if New York Balks on Subsidies

Amid the glamour and the French Riviera sun, more and more Wall Street banks, private equity firms and hedge funds are coming to the 12-day Cannes festival – the world’s largest international film market – to try to arrange and finance entertainment deals.

Merrill Lynch, Citigroup, and JPMorgan Chase, as well as hedge funds like Atticus Capital and various companies backed by the likes of Providence Equity Partners and the Texas Pacific Group, are all here this year, competing for deals.
In Cannes, Bankers May Outnumber Movie Stars

JPMorgan Chase has picked up its first advisory mandate from the Nasdaq Stock Market since standing down as financial adviser on the exchange’s hostile bid for the London Stock Exchange to avoid a conflict of interest.
JPMorgan Back on Board in Nasdaq’s Latest Exchange Deal
PQ, a specialty chemical manufacturer, is being sold for the second time in less than three years, bringing its owner a huge profit.

The Carlyle Group said Friday that it had agreed to pay $1.5 billion for the company, making it a home run for the private-equity arm of JPMorgan Chase, which bought PQ for $626 million in February 2005.
Carlyle’s Deal for PQ Reaps Big Windfall for JPMorgan
Ray Dalio, the founder of Bridgewater Associates, has some tough questions on why hedge fund returns look so much like returns in the stock market.
As Money Pours in, Hedge Funds Come to Look More Like the Markets
JPMorgan and Goldman Sachs have been hired by Apollo Management to advise on on its expected initial public offering.

The Financial Times said late Wednesday that this is the first sign of a comeback by other Wall Street banks after the early dominance of Morgan Stanley and Citigroup in the battle to underwrite private equity floats.
J.P. Morgan, Goldman May Advise Apollo I.P.O.
COMPANY REPORTS Earnings season gets into full swing, particularly for technology, financial and drug companies.

Reports will come from Charles Schwab and Mattel (Monday); Coca-Cola, I.B.M., Intel, Johnson & Johnson, Merrill Lynch, Novartis, Wells Fargo and Yahoo (Tuesday); Abbott Laboratories, Altria, AMR, Delta Air Lines, eBay, JPMorgan Chase, Pfizer, Southwest Airlines and United Technologies (Wednesday); Advanced Micro Devices, Bank of America, Bank of New York Mellon, Continental Airlines, Dow Jones, First Data, Google, Honeywell, Microsoft, Motorola and Wyeth (Thursday); and Boston Scientific, Caterpillar and Citigroup (Friday).
Looking Ahead
Canadian retail sales rose in May at the fastest rate in almost a decade, adding to pressure on the country’s central bank to keep raising interest rates.
Sales rose 2.8 percent, to 35 billion Canadian dollars ($33.7 billion), Statistics Canada said.
May’s increase was the fastest since December 1997, the statistics agency said.

The retail sales report “pretty much cements the September rate hike and raises some questions about whether the bank might need to do more before the end of the year,” said Ted Carmichael, chief Canadian economist for JPMorgan Securities in Toronto.
Canada: Retail Sales Rose in May

Citigroup‘s exposure to indigestion in the leveraged loan market and turmoil in the subprime mortgage business remains a concern, but problems with the asset-backed commercial paper market seem to be ebbing slightly, analysts at JPMorgan Chase said on Tuesday.
Citigroup’s L.B.O.
Deals Remain a Concern, Analysts Say

Deutsche Bank and JPMorgan Chase have found buyers for the highest yielding loans financing Kohlberg Kravis Roberts‘ purchase of the British pharmacist Alliance Boots in a sign demand for credit may be improving.
Banks Said to Find Buyers for Boots Debt
JPMorgan Chase & Company has named Tom Lee chief United States equity strategist, filling the position formerly held by Abhijit Chakrabortti, who has joined Morgan Stanley.
JPMorgan Names Chief Equity Strategist
Britain’s Northern Rock turned down an offer of 500 million pounds ($1 billion) in funding from JPMorgan Chase that could have eased its liquidity problems, the Daily Telegraph reported.
Northern Rock Said to Reject JPMorgan Funding
Fidelity Investments on Thursday named JPMorgan Chase‘s Michael K. Clark to head its new institutional services business, tapping another outsider as part of the company’s continuing reorganization.
Fidelity Taps JPMorgan Executive
A group of infrastructure funds led by JPMorgan Chase agreed to buy a British water company Southern Water from the Royal Bank of Scotland for about 1.3 billion pounds ($2.7 billion).
JPMorgan Group Laps Up Southern Water for $2.7 Billion
JPMorgan Chase said on Thursday it was making modest staff reductions in areas that include structured credit and leveraged finance.
The cuts are expected to be less than 10 percent in each.
J.P. Morgan to Cut Jobs in Fixed Income Unit
A sell-off in technology shares led U.S. markets lower, as concerns arose that the prices of computer-related stocks were outpacing their profit outlook.
Technology and Retail Worries Halt Rally
Citigroup, Bank of America and JPMorgan Chase plan to create a $75 billion to $100 billion fund to buy bonds and other debt at a time when many investors are avoiding them.
Banks to Start Fund to Protect Credit Market
Citigroup, Bank of America and JPMorgan Chase are  creating a fund to buy bonds and other debt at a time when many investors are avoiding them.
Banks Create a Fund to Protect Credit Market

Citigroup, Bank of America and JPMorgan Chase, working together at the behest of the Treasury Department, announced Monday that they are creating a large fund to serve as a buyer of bonds and other debt at a time when many investors are avoiding them.
Banks to Start Fund to Protect Credit Market

Industry observers seemed to cast a jaundiced eye yesterday over a plan unveiled by Citigroup, Bank of America and JPMorgan Chase, with active encouragement from the Treasury Department, to keep the housing-related debt crisis from worsening.
Is Banks’ Funding Plan Just Spin?
A former Dow Chemical executive sued JPMorgan, contending that the bank deceived Dow by not disclosing its role in unauthorized buyout discussions.
Fired Dow Chemical Officer Sues JPMorgan
Strong performances in the bank’s asset management, credit card groups and treasury services groups helped offset troubles in the investment banking unit.
JPMorgan Chase Posts a Profit, but Takes $2 Billion Write-Down
JPMorgan Chase is considering acquiring a stake in a Chinese brokerage as part of its expansion strategy in the country, its leading executive in Asia told The Financial Times.
JPMorgan Hankers for Chinese Brokerage Deal
Bankrupt Delphi has revealed the lending group that has agreed to provide close to $7 billion to help the insolvent auto parts maker emerge from court protection.
Delphi Gets Exit Financing From Citigroup and JPMorgan

After months of complicated negotiations, officials from Bank of America, Citigroup and JPMorgan Chase have agreed on the structure of a backup fund for credit markets, said a person involved in discussions.
Banks Said to Agree on Credit Backup Fund

After several painful days of declines, stock markets moved into positive territory Tuesday as the Dow Jones industrials surged nearly 320 points on sunnier forecasts from Wal-Mart, as well as JPMorgan Chase and Goldman Sachs.
But many analysts doubted the high spirits would last.
Banks’ Good News Helps Spark Market Rally, for Now
Amaranth Advisors, the hedge fund that failed last year after losing $6.5 billion, sued JPMorgan Chase, accusing the bank of sabotaging its efforts to stave off collapse.
Amaranth Sues JPMorgan Over Fund’s Collapse

JPMorgan Chase and Commonwealth Bank of Australia agreed to buy the United Utilities power-distribution unit in Britain for £1.14 billion ($2.34 billion), adding electricity customers to their British water assets.
Britain: Banks Buy Utility
JPMorgan Chase announced on Monday that it has appointed Barry Zubrow as its chief risk officer, a position that had been vacant since Don Wilson retired last year.
In some ways, though, the bank seems to have done better than its rivals even without an official top risk manager — for now, at least.
A Smoother Ride for JPMorgan’s New Risk Chief?
JPMorgan Chase said Monday it will invest $200 million in film and entertainment projects to add to its entertainment advisory and banking operations.
The New York investment bank said it will use subordinated debt for investments such as film and television financings, acquisitions and print and digital media start-ups.
JPMorgan to Invest $200 Million in the Movies
Barron’s apparently likes the looks of JPMorgan Chase‘s prospects.

In a bullish feature on Chase, the nation’s third-largest bank, the publication noted that JPMorgan avoided most of the losses suffered by other investment banks and its growth could now “really accelerate.”
A Bullish Look at JPMorgan
One Equity Partners agreed to sell its stake in Quintiles Transnational, a big manager of clinical drug trials, to its C.E.O.
and two buyout firms.
A Buyout for Manager of Drug Trials
Poor Blackstone Group.
Everything seems to be going wrong for it these days.
Last week Blackstone’s buy-out of PHH and its mortgage service business collapsed amidst reports of acrimony between Blackstone and its bankers JPMorgan Chase and Lehman Brothers.
The deal cost Blackstone some reputational capital and perhaps a financing relationship or two.
A Closer Look at the Alliance Data Deal
Stephen Schwarzman has been forced to eat a rare slice of humble pie on Wall Street.

Schwarzman, chief executive of the Blackstone Group, went hat in hand to JPMorgan Chase and Lehman Brothers in an effort to mend fences after the banks pulled the plug on his $1.8 billion deal to acquire PHH, The New York Post reported.
Schwarzman Said to Offer Olive Branch to Banks

JPMorgan Chase plans to add at least 700 staff to its Asia-Pacific headquarters in Hong Kong over the next three years and lease up to 11 floors in a new office block to accommodate the growth, Reuters reported.
JPMorgan Plans Asia Hiring Spree
A new JPMorgan Chase campaign aims to overcome cluttered airwaves, nervous customers and cuts in marketing budgets.
Trying to Be Heard Above the Din, and Be Trusted
In bank advertising, what matters is getting noticed at a time when the airwaves are cluttered, customers are nervous and marketing budgets are being slashed.
JPMorgan Chase has that in mind with a sleek new brand campaign aimed at unifying its consumer advertising, streamlining its message and stretching the dollars it spends.
In New Ads, JPMorgan Tries to Be Heard Above the Din
Britain’s former prime minister, Tony Blair, will join the banking giant JPMorgan Chase & Company as a part-time adviser, a person with knowledge of the decision said Wednesday night.
Tony Blair Expected to Join JPMorgan
The former prime minister of Britain, Tony Blair, will join the banking giant JPMorgan Chase as a part-time adviser, the bank said.
Tony Blair to Join JPMorgan as Adviser

Northern Rock, one of Britain’s biggest casualties of the credit crisis, sold part of its mortgage portfolio to JPMorgan as it seeks to repay about £25 billion, or $49 billion, in emergency financing.
Northern Rock Sells Some Assets

Buyout Bust Cuts Into Fees to Banks, Report Finds

Britain’s troubled Northern Rock has sold a 2.2 billion pound ($4.3 billion) portfolio of mortgages to JPMorgan Chase, a first step to help the troubled lender repay loans from the Bank of England, Reuters reported.
Northern Rock to Sell Portfolio to JPMorgan
Charlie Gasparino of CNBC discusses talk of a link-up between JPMorgan and Washington Mutual.
CNBC Stirs JPMorgan-WaMu Talk
Northern Rock, one of Europe’s biggest casualties of the credit crisis, sold some of its mortgage portfolio to JPMorgan Chase.

JPMorgan Chase said its fourth-quarter net income fell 34 percent as problems from the housing slump widened in its investment banking and consumer businesses.
JPMorgan Joins Banks in Write-Downs
Mortgage troubles are spreading to credit cards and auto loans.
Quarterly Income Slips at JPMorgan, Ending Record Year but Hinting at Concerns

Investors cheered JPMorgan Chase on Wednesday, underscoring how, in these troubled times on Wall Street, a drop in profits can still make a firm look like a champion — mostly because the drop wasn’t worse.
JPMorgan’s Stock Surges Despite Profit Drop

William B. Harrison, the former chairman and chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, has joined the investment advisory committee of the Aurora Capital Group, a private equity firm that acquired midsize companies, Aurora said Monday.

Mr. Harrison, who oversaw JP Morgan’s $58 billion merger with Bank One in 2004, will help Los Angeles-based Aurora identify potential investments and evaluate potential executives to run its portfolio companies, the firm said
Ex-JPMorgan Chief to Advise Buyout Firm
A January report by JPMorgan Chase said growing revenues from online advertising would in part lead to a great year for Internet stocks.
Bullish About the Web

JPMorgan Chase announced a major push on Monday into private-equity investing in Asia, saying it had earmarked at least $750 million of its own capital to take minority stakes in businesses in a region where buyouts are notoriously difficult.
JPMorgan to Funnel $750 Million into Asia Private Equity Fund
Robert Pickering has resigned from his post as chief executive of Cazenove, the British bank, in a surprise move that has triggered speculation about its future.
Cazenove Boss Resigns Amid Reported Tensions With JPMorgan
JPMorgan Chase retained its position as the largest hedge fund manager in the United States as total assets of the biggest hedge fund firms topped $1.6 trillion as of Jan. 1.
Ranking the Biggest Hedge-Fund Firms

Some Wall Street wizardry, he said, could lighten their load.
High Finance Backfires on Alabama County

Jumping into the are-we-aren’t-we-in-a-recession debate, JPMorgan Chase‘s chief executive, James Dimon, told a group of economists in Washington on Wednesday that the United States is likely in recession already and the housing market is expected to deteriorate further.
JPMorgan’s Dimon Says Recession May Be Upon U.S.
Facing a grave liquidity crisis, Bear Stearns reached out for a financial lifeline and now faces the prospect of the end of its 85-year run as an independent investment bank.
JPMorgan and Fed Move to Bail Out Bear Stearns

Duration Capital, one of several hedge funds forced to sell hundreds of millions of dollars of municipal bonds when their bets went awry, is severing its links with its main prime broker, JPMorgan Chase, according to Reuters.
Duration Capital Said to Cut All Ties With JPMorgan
Bear Stearns agreed to be bought by JPMorgan Chase for a bargain-basement price of less than $250 million, or about $2 a share.
JPMorgan Acts to Buy Ailing Bear Stearns at Huge Discount

Updated 7:25 p.m. Bear Stearns, facing collapse because of the mortgage crisis, agreed Sunday evening to be bought by JPMorgan Chase for a bargain-basement price of less than $250 million, the two companies announced.
Bear Stearns to Sell Itself to JPMorgan for $2 a Share
Update: Bear Stearns has agreed to sell itself to JPMorgan Chase for $2 a share.
The firm’s shares closed at $30 on Friday, giving it a market value of $4.1 billion.
For DealBook’s full coverage of the Bear Stearns crisis, go here.

Recapping the JPMorgan Conference Call

JPMorgan’s Expanding Footprint
How long will it take?
Can JPMorgan Chase refuse to complete the deal if things get even worse for Bear Stearns?
And can Bear’s shareholders, facing an almost complete loss, stop it?
A Few Questions About the Bear Stearns Deal
In a shocking deal reached on Sunday to save Bear Stearns, JPMorgan Chase agreed to pay less than one-tenth the firm’s market price on Friday.
JP Morgan Pays $2 a Share for Bear Stearns
Concerns about the fallout from the bargain-basement sale of Bear Stearns to JPMorgan Chase drove Asian and Europe stocks lower, and U.S. futures plunged overnight.
Shares Slide on Fed Move and Bear Deal
JPMorgan Chase will pay just $2 a share for Bear Stearns — less than one-tenth the firm’s market price on Friday.
Sale Price Reflects the Depth of Bear’s Problems

Bear Stearns‘s shocking deal to sell itself to JPMorgan Chase for a mere $2 per share — less than one-tenth the firm’s market price on Friday — underscored how few options remained for Bear, which was driven to the brink of bankruptcy by what amounted to a run on the bank.
The Bear Stearns Bailout
Will JPMorgan Chase’s stunning $2 a share deal to buy Bear Stearns put a crimp in Visa‘s plans to go public this week in what is expected to be the nation’s biggest initial public offering?
Will Bear Deal Delay Visa Offering?
Bear Stearns‘s fire sale to JPMorgan Chase could lead to a “major negative revaluation” of financial stocks, Meredith Whitney, an analyst at Oppenheimer & Company, wrote in a research note.
She suggested they could fall by as much as 50 percent.
Bear Deal Could Slam Financial Stocks, Analyst Says

Agreeing to guarantee a 28-day credit line to Bear Stearns, by way of JPMorgan Chase, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York conceded last Friday that no sizable firm with a book of mortgage securities or loans out to mortgage issuers could be allowed to fail right now.

For The New York Times’ Gretchen Morgenson, it was the most explicit sign yet of the Fed’s “Rescues ‘R’ Us” doctrine that already helped to force the marriage of Bank of America and Countrywide Financial.
Rescue Me: A Fed Bailout Crosses a Line
CNBC looks back at the fateful year leading up to Bear Stearns's takeover by JPMorgan.
A Fateful Year for Bear Stearns
CNBC's David Faber outlines the reasons why Bear Stearns was compelled to sell itself to JPMorgan Chase, even at a low price.
Bear Stearns' $2-a-Share Sale
It’s not surprising that Bear Stearns‘s stock plummeted Monday after JPMorgan Chase agreed to buy it for just $2 per share.
The surprising part is that it didn’t plummet even more.
Could Bear Stearns Do Better?
It’s not surprising that Bear Stearns’s stock plummeted after JPMorgan Chase agreed to buy it for just $2 per share.
The surprising part is that it didn’t plummet more.

JPMorgan Chase is obviously acquiring a lot in its $236 million purchase of Bear Stearns.
For pennies on the dollar, the banking giant is buying extensive prime brokerage and clearing operations, as well as a $1.2 billion office building.
What to Do With Bear’s C.E.O.
Bear Stearns’s downfall and subsequent sale to JPMorgan Chase on Sunday was orchestrated by some of the most powerful people on Wall Street and in Washington.
Saving Wall St. (for Now)
Since the mortgage market crisis unfolded in the summer, investors have fretted that Lehman will stumble, and its stock has fallen from a peak of $82 a share then.
At Lehman, Allaying Fears About Being the Next to Fall
For employees of Bear Stearns, many of whom have spent most of their professional lives at Bear, the sudden collapse was unfathomable.
Aftershocks of a Collapse, With a Bank at the Epicenter

While Bear Stearns‘ $2 per share deal to sell itself to JPMorgan may have given some investors like billionaire Joseph Lewis a sense of inverted sticker-shock, those who seem to be suffering most from the news of the firesale are Bear’s own employees.
Aftershocks of Bear’s Collapse
Shocked by the rapid demise of Bear Stearns and its fire sale to JPMorgan Chase, investors sold off the stock of Lehman Brothers and several other financial firms Monday.
At Lehman, Allaying Fears About Being the Next to Fall
Over the weekend, the Federal Reserve bailed out JPMorgan Chase.
JPMorgan’s $12 Billion Bailout
A battle seems to be brewing in the markets over the fate of the troubled investment bank.
Bondholders like the JPMorgan deal, but Bear’s shareholders hope to scuttle it.
It’s Bondholders vs. Shareholders in a Race to Buy Bear Stearns Stock

Only days after the fire sale of Bear Stearns stunned Wall Street, a battle seems to be brewing in the markets over the fate of the troubled investment bank and the controversial deal that JPMorgan and federal authorities devised to save it.
Bear’s Stock Becomes a Battlefield
James Dimon may have solidified his reputation for deal-making savvy with JPMorgan Chase‘s stunning deal for Bear Stearns But his firm may not be putting its checkbook away yet.
Is JPMorgan’s Buying Spree Only Beginning?
Bear Stearns shareholders are understandably furious about the investment bank’s sale to JPMorgan Chase for about $2 a share.
Now one of the largest of them is warning that he intends to try and stop it.
Unhappy Billionaire Prepares to Act on Bear Deal
James Dimon, the chairman and chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, attempted to win over executives at Bear Stearns who have vowed to fight his offer.
At Bear Stearns, Meet the New Boss
The audacious government-orchestrated purchase of Bear Stearns by JPMorgan Chase has dominated headlines and chatter this week.
To say there are a plethora of angles to cover — the $2-a-share price, the role of the government, the challenges in closing the deal — is an understatement.
Discussing Bear Stearns’ Deal
Borders Group, the struggling bookstore chain, said Thursday it hired JPMorgan and Merrill Lynch to explore strategic alternatives, including a sale of all or part of the company.
Shares of Borders initially rose in Friday trading but soon moved sharply lower.
Borders to Consider Selling Itself

JPMorgan in Negotiations to Raise Bear Stearns Bid
The offer is intended to win over angry shareholders in Bear who vowed to fight the original fire-sale deal.
JPMorgan Raises Bid for Bear Stearns to $10 a Share

JPMorgan Chase was in talks on Sunday night for a deal that would quintuple its offer for Bear Stearns, the beleaguered investment bank, in an effort to pacify angry Bear shareholders, the New York Times reported citing people involved in the negotiations.
JPMorgan in Talks to Raise Bear Stearns Bid

JPMorgan was last week rushing to reassure hedge fund clients of Bear Stearns‘ prime brokerage of its commitment to the business to prevent an exodus of assets before the integration, according to Financial News.

In the week or so since the Federal Reserve Bank of New York pushed Bear Stearns into the arms of JPMorgan Chase, there has been much buzz about why the deal went down precisely as it did.

Bear’s Big Guarantee

Monday brought a rare bit of good news for Bear Stearns‘ beleaguered shareholders: The New York Times reported that JPMorgan Chase was in talks over the weekend to raise its bid for Bear to $10 per share from $2 per share.
CNBC Video: Chase’s Talks to Raise Bear Bid
It’s official: JPMorgan Chase and Bear Stearns have announced new terms for their merger deal, confirming Monday’s report in The New York Times.

The new agreement raises JPMorgan’s offer for Bear to $10 per share in JPMorgan’s stock, up from $2 per share, quintupling the payout for shareholders of Bear, the securities firm that nearly collapsed earlier this month amid concerns about its liquidity.
JPMorgan Raises Bear Bid to $10 Per Share
In scrambling to patch the mistakes in their previous deal with Bear Stearns, JPMorgan and its attorneys at Wachtell Lipton Rosen & Katz may have put themselves in a newly precarious position.
Is JPMorgan Getting Too Clever?
Already, Bear Stearns has posted to its Web site all of the amended agreements in connection with its price renegotiation.
(You can read the amended merger agreement here and the amended guarantee agreement here, both as PDFs.)
JPMorgan and Bear Test the Limits
JPMorgan’s improved offer illustrates the deep complexity and political sensitivity of the deal, which also met the rejection and anger of Bear Stearns shareholders and employees.
Seeking Fast Deal, JPMorgan Quintuples Bear Stearns Bid
Thanks to Visa’s blockbuster initial public offering last week, JPMorgan Chase won’t have to look very hard to come up with the extra money for its sweetened bid for Bear Stearns.
JPMorgan Reaps $1.36 Billion from Visa I.P.O.

The decision by James Dimon, JPMorgan Chase’s chief executive, to raise his bank’s bid for Bear Stearns from $2 a share to $10 dollars a share illustrates the deep complexity and political sensitivity of a deal with participants who reached into the highest corners of Washington, from the Treasury to the Federal Reserve System, according to The New York Times.
The Complexities Behind JPMorgan’s $10 Bear Offer
Now that JPMorgan Chase has quintupled to $10 a share its offer for Bear Stearns, many are asking whether this marks the end of the takeover saga, or just the beginning of a new chapter.
Investors Betting on a Bigger Bear Bid May Disappointed
JPMorgan Chase‘s new $10 offer for Bear Stearns was certainly audacious.
But just as stunning was the reach and influence of an unexpected player in the drama, according to Andrew Ross Sorkin in his weekly DealBook column.
Ben Bernanke, Deal Maker

JPMorgan to Acquire ClimateCare

In a Day of Downgrades, Merrill Takes a Hit
Senators are demanding information about how the Federal Reserve arranged the $30 billion shotgun marriage of JPMorgan Chase and Bear Stearns.
Senators Seek Details About Bear Stearns Deal

Senior senators signaled their unease on Wednesday with the Federal Reserve’s shotgun marriage of JPMorgan Chase and Bear Stearns, demanding detailed information by next week about how the $30 billion deal was reached.

The judge said he plans to issue a written ruling on the matter in the next several days.

Dimon’s Compensation Rose 5% at JPMorgan
The markets are global, but the decision-making isn’t.
Therein lies the danger that transcends borders.
Leveraged Planet
